BLIST.ITEM:
Pairwise Testinghttp://www.pairwise.org

enHTML

enHTML: keyword driven tests

Seleniumhttp://seleniumhq.org

list: testingfaqs.orghttp://www.testingfaqs.org/t-eval.html
enHTML

PrtScrhttp://www.fiastarta.com/PrtScr
enHTML: a powerful screenshot tool

Winkhttp://www.debugmode.com/wink/
enHTML: recording a film of the screen

X.T: Virtual PC Images to test IE

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Brian Marick
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author gives a good list of errors commonly done, I've already met several of them. The list is not exhaustive, the proposed solutions could have been more analyzed, but this is a good brain catalyst to think about how to improve your testing.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good checklist to design test strategies.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to prove to managers the value of testing...

X.T: A Framework for Good Enough Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James provide some questions to ask oneself when having to decide what what should be the test effort.

X.T: What's So Different About Game Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Duri Price
Ilya Pearlman
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why is game testing different from testing usual applications?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Cem Kaner
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cem describes some trivial and some more interesting facts on testing (especially about good enough quality).

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anindita Sarkar
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about testing (requirement writing, test prioritization, reporting...). There is nothing new here, but this description is interestingly down to earth.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James explains how you, being a good tester, can reach the status of being a testing expert. This does not speak about testing tools or methodologies, but on the state of mind you should have.

X.T: Open Lecture by James Bach on Software Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A longer, updated version of the previous presentation.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Bertrand Meyer
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Meyer presents some interesting ideas, for example the fact that testing strategies must be assessed. But I tend to sometimes disagree : testing is not only finding bugs, but it is also checking that common use scenarios are successfully supported; adding a new test for every found bug will result into a chaos if there isn't a good testing infrastructure...

X.T: How To Recruit, Motivate, and Energize Superior Test Engineers

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jeff Feldstein
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A test manager at CISCO explains how he hires and retains test engineers.

X.T: Proving Our Worth: Quantifying the Value of Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Lee Copeland
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Lee starts by looking for a definition of testing. Then, he speaks about the goal/question/metric model and the fact that some companies collect metrics without any purpose. He explains that information should be accurate, timely, complete, relevant, unique, and actionable. He finishes by explaining the information that developers, test managers, and project managers would like to have. This lecture is interesting, but too much abstract. For example, in most cases, it is impossible to give a dollar estimation of a bug.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jamie Andrews
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
Some research on software testing: randomized tests (I used this fourteen years ago...), mutant generator, Tarantulahttp://pleuma.cc.gatech.edu/aristotle/Tools/tarantula/
enHTML...

X.T: Diagnosing Java code: Unit tests and automated code analysis working together - Your tests can help your tools to analyze your code

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Eric E. Allen
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Unit tests and code analysis complete each other, but I am not sure the technologies are mature enough today to have an interesting return on investment when applied.

X.T: The Anti-Virus or Anti-Malware test file

ARTICLE.COMMENT: EICAR created a dummy virus which is recognized by antivirus software of most vendors.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James McCaffrey
ARTICLE.COMMENT: If the function being tested has some particularities (symmetry, recurrence relations...), it is possible to generate new test cases from existing ones.
The very well known software testing sample.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Elisabeth Hendrickson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hendrickson shares her experience of being a tester in an XP team: this is a very practical and interesting paper...

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Elisabeth Hendrickson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same information as in the article above, but, here, you get additionally her full dynamism.
An interesting group discussion on Scrum and QA.

X.T: Exploratory Testing in an Agile Context

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Elisabeth Hendrickson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A tutorial explaining some ways to perform exploratory testing.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Simon Stewart
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The description of how Google defines test sizes (small vs medium vs large).

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Engineering Productivity organisation.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Two

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The different engineering roles.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Three

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Development and testing are intricately linked.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - A Brief Interlude

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James Whittaker explains why he is not joking about developers as he used to.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alberto Savoia
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Change Risk Anti-Patterns metric.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Four

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The channels corresponding to the release maturity: canary channel, dev channel, test channel, and release channel.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Five

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How Google classifies tests: small tests, medium tests, and large tests.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The differences between an SWE (Software Engineer) and an SET (Software Engineer in Test).

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Six

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: SETs are not involved at the beginning of the project and not all projects even have SETs in their team.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - A Break for Q&A

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Switching between SWE and SET position, people can remain Individual Contributors rather than becoming managers.

X.T: How Google Tests Software - Part Seven

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Test Engineer role.

X.T: Testing at the speed and scale of Google

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Pooja Gupta
Mark Ivey
John Penix
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google performs concurrent builds and is using dependency analysis to run less tests after each build.

X.T: Lessons in a 21st Century Tech Career: Failing Fast, 20% Time and Project Mobility

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title indicates what James Whittaker believes to be the factors that make Googlers so dedicated to their work.

X.T: How We Tested Google Instant Pages

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jason Arbon
Tejas Shah
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James Whittaker explains that he gives his teams 10 minutes to build a test plan. In fact, they are able to build 80% of this one in 30 minutes by using an AAC (attribute / component / capability) model.

X.T: Take a BITE out of Bugs and Redundant Labor

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is open sourcing the "head up display" that James Whittaker described in his GTAC 2010 presentation.

X.T: Google JS Test, now in Open Source

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Aaron Jacobs
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google releases a JavaScript unit test framework as open source.

X.T: Google Test Analytics - Now in Open Source

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jim Reardon
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google releases, as open source, a tool to create an ACC matrix and aggregate metrics (test cases, test results, commits,...) about it.

X.T: ScriptCover makes Javascript coverage analysis easy

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ekaterina Kamenskaya
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google releases an open source JavaScript code coverage tool.

X.T: EuroSTAR Software Testing Video: Ten Minute Test Plan with James Whittaker

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of how Google tests: ten minutes test plan, ACC, risk analysis...

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anthony F. Voellm
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Testing is integrated to coding, so done by developers. SET s and TEs are providing expertise in particular for security, reliability, and performance. Nothing new here. I guess Google is just trying to hire more TEs and SETs.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alan Myrvold
Alan Faulkner
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The interview of a Google Test Engineer. Once again nothing new here, this is a hiring advertisement.

X.T: Why Are There So Many C++ Testing Frameworks?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Zhanyong Wan
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why they are so many C++ test framework and some Google Test design choices.

X.T: Testing on the Toilet: Testing State vs. Testing Interactions

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Andrew Trenk
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After explaining the difference between testing states and testing interactions, the author explains that we should test states except in some particular cases.

X.T: Does It Work? Are We Done? Is It Right? (Keep It Light!)

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jim Shore
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
(The transcript is available in Does It Work? Are We Done? Is It Right? (Keep It Light!)http://www.jamesshore.com/Blog/Does-It-Work-Are-We-Done.html
enHTML) TDD is the solution to minimize waste when checking if the software works properly and it is complete.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James describes what he calls Exploratory Testing: having bright minds executing tests designed on the fly. I can only agree with him: this works only if the tester is good.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jon Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
(The slides are available in Breaking Down (and building up) Exploratory Testing Skillhttp://www.quardev.com/content/whitepapers/ET_dynamics_Google_3_06.pdf
enPDF.) Jon Bach gives some information about exploratory testing. He lists 14 usable tactics ("MRQ COMP GRABC R&R?"). This is a good brain teaser, but the presentation is rather messy.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
(The blog entry and the slides are available herehttp://www.satisfice.com/blog/archives/87
enHTML.) James explains that models are always wrong and you will miss bugs if you blindly base your tests on such a model. During the Q&A session, James discusses about some of his favourite subjects: MIPping (mention in passing), blink testing...

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: James gives a realistic view of automatic testing.

X.T: Seven Steps to Test Automation Success

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Bret Pettichord
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of test automation with some very good practical comments.

X.T: When Should a Test Be Automated?
When Should a Test Be Automated?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Brian Marick
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some ideas about the factors to be taken into account to decide for automated tests vs manual tests.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Robert Chatley
Tom White
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The two guys have created a test framework in which tests are readable by non-software persons. Despite what they say, I am still doubting a lot about this interest of this...

X.T: Why Automated Testing for Web Apps?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Kevin Nilson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of tools, very quickly described, for unit tests, test automation, and continuous integration of Web applications.

X.T: Google Test Automation Conference Lightning Talks

BLIST.TITLE: Some lighting talks:
BLIST.ITEM: automated test and lean manufacturing/product design
jMock
jMock2 vs jMock1
how to explain the value of automated test to non-IT persons
building a database of User Agent capabilities
some advertisement for ThoughtWorks
take into account the JavaScript execution time on the client PC
how to sell automated test?
some tests need to be manual but manual testers need to use their brain more than their hands so they require stuff like snippets of automation, bulk comparison, and virtual machines
avoiding single point of failure in test strategies: integrating the testing levels and the development tools, and TestQuest
Test Anything Protocol

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Christopher Semturs
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Patrick Copeland presents Google testing: the challenge to test complex systems, having developers writing tests, certification within one day...

X.T: GTAC 2008: Advances in Automated Software Testing Technologies

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Elfriede Dustin
Marcus Borch
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
The speakers describe how their company, Innovative Defense Technologieshttp://www.innovativedefense.com/
enHTML, is using many open source tools to automatically generate automated tests.

X.T: GTAC 2008: The Value of Small Tests

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Christopher Semturs
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How a tester can/should educate developers to perform tests by using dependency injection and mocks.

X.T: GTAC 2008: The New Genomics - Software Development at Petabyte Scale

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Matt Wood
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A description of the hardware/software the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institutehttp://www.sanger.ac.uk
enHTML uses to handle 75 petabytes of data per week.

X.T: GTAC 2008: Taming the Beast - How to Test an AJAX Application

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Markus Clermont
John Thomas
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Markus and John suggest testing each layer independently, then testing layer pairs, and at last doing a few tests on the whole system. The quick informal survey of the audience is also interesting.

X.T: GTAC 2008: Practicing Testability in the Real World

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Vishal Chowdhary
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Vishal arguments why testability should be taken into account when designing software. He also describes the SOCK principle: Simplicity, Observability, Control, and Knowledge.

X.T: GTAC 2009 - Precondition Satisfaction by Smart Object Select

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Yi Wei
Serge Gebhardt
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to get better random tests by selecting only the inputs objects that fulfil the preconditions.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Michael Tamm
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Michael Tamm presents three ways to find some layout bugs: validating the HTML, validating the CSS, and, his real novelty, writing some heuristics to analyze the page.

X.T: GTAC 2009 - Achieving Web Test Automation with a Mixed-Skill

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mark Micallef
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Mark Micallef explains how he has started to use cucumber to allow different types of profiles (analysts vs enginers) to test web sites and .NET applications.

X.T: GTAC 2009 - Automatic Workarounds for Web Applications

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mauro Pezzè
Alessandra Gorla
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study creating a database of workarounds and trying to apply them automatically when the user reports a failure. I am not sure of the interest of this: this cannot be used for applications modifying data (the data would be garbaged by the workaround tries), this can probably work only for some scripting languages, the set of bug types must be limited...

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Sylvain Hallé
Fred Beringer
David Conti
Jason Huggins
Raphaël Marvie
Alec Munru
Chritiane Phillips
Weiwei Cheng
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some random subjects with a few interesting presentations.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Joshua Williams
Ross Smith
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The speakers suggest using games, inside a company, to perform some testing activities. They give the example of crowdsourcing (internally to Microsoft) the review of Windows 7 localizations.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jeremie Lenfant-Engelmann
Ross Smith
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of JsTextDriver, a JavaScript test-running platform able to drive several browsers in parallel.

X.T: GTAC 2009 - Automated Performance Test Data Collection and Reporting

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: David Burns
David Henderson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of an automated performance measurement and reporting environment. YSlow is used for generating the data.

X.T: GTAC 2010: The Future of Front-End Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Simon Stewart
Greg Dennis
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on automated front-end tests, Selenium, and the good and bad things looming in the future.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Crowd Source Testing, Mozilla Community Style

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Matt Evans
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on Mozilla testing process.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Special Lightning Talk - Testivus on Testability

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alberto Savoia
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The humorous karma of unit testing.

X.T: GTAC 2010: What Testability Tells Us About the Software Performance Envelope

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Robert V. Binder
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A general presentation on testing where Robert V. Binder claims that model-based testing enables to improve by two orders of magnitude the test productivity and the resulting product reliability.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Automatically Generating Test Data for Web Applications

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jeff Offutt
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Most of this talk is general information about testing which has been heard thousands times before, only the Automated Test Data Generation part is interesting.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Lessons Learned from Testability Failures

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Esteban Manchado Velázquez
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some examples from Opera where the software was not properly testable and why testability is important.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Turning Quality on its Head

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Whittaker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After some general comment on developers vs testers, a presentation of Testify, a tool based on ACC (Attribute / Component / Capability) to help testers being more productive.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Flexible Design? Testable Design? You Don't Have To Choose!

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Russ Rufer
Tracy Bialik
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Russ and Tracy describe some design mistakes, describe how to fix them, and explain why the fixed design also results into a better testability.

X.T: GTAC 2010: Twist, A Next Generation Functional Testing Tool for Building and Evolving Test Suites

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Vivek Prahlad
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Twist, a tool to write test scenario at a functional level.

X.T: GTAC 2011: Opening Keynote Address - Test is Dead

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alberto Savoia
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The evolution of testing: from building it right to building the right it, by using pretotyping / Minimum Viable Product.

X.T: GTAC 2011: Keynote - How Hackers See Bugs

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Hugh Thompson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some random ideas about security, there is nothing new here, but Hugh Thompson is a good showman.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Williams
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a short introduction to WebGL, some advice on testing applications using it and the announcement of GLSL-Unit, a unit testing framework to test shaders.

X.T: GTAC 2011: BidiChecker: Automated Bidi Testing of Web Applications

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Yana Margolin
Jason Elbaum
ARTICLE.COMMENT: First, a description of the bidi problem, then a presentation of a tool to detect bidi bugs.

X.T: GTAC 2011: How to Hit a Moving Target in the Cloud

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Vishal Chowdhary
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How Microsoft is testing its translator service, a piece of software whose results are always evolving.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roussi Roussev
Chris Chen
Timothy Crooks
Ekaterina Kamenskaya
Sai Chintala
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using the cloud for testing, ScriptCover (a JS test coverage tool), SalesForce testing infrastructure...

X.T: GTAC 2011: Keynote - Part the Clouds and See Fact from Fiction

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anthony Voellm
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some very high level information about the cloud and about testing in it. Nevertheless, the whole overview is OK.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Simon Stewart
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to create a test infrastructure using WebDriver.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Dounia Berrada
David Clarke
Matt DeVore
David Burns
Jerome Mueller
ARTICLE.COMMENT: WebDriver for mobiles, writing tests in plain English, heat map, NativeDriver to test native iOS and Android applications...

X.T: GTAC 2011: The Latest in Google Test Tools

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ibrahim El Far
Jason Arbon
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of BITE (the "head up display" bug reporting system that James Whittaker described in the past) and of some quality bots.

X.T: GTAC 2011: Closing Keynote - Secrets of World Class Software Organizations

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steve McConnell
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The common traits of the best software companies: hiring the best talents, strong sense of mission, business accountability, commitment to quality, frequent introspection, practices adapted to teams, all of these resulting into a high commitment of the staff.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ken Kania
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new version of WebDriver for Chrome is available, aiming at supporting all platforms. This talk quickly describes how this new version has been implemented.

X.T: GTAC 2013: Karma - Test Runner for JavaScript

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Vojta Jina
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Description of Karma, a JavaScript Unit Test runner.

X.T: GTAC 2013 Day 1 Closing Keynote: How Facebook Tests Facebook on Android

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Simon Stewart
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Facebook development environment: each team develops its features on all platforms, Git with one branch, homemade build system, tests...

X.T: GTAC 2013 Day 2 Keynote: Testable JavaScript - Architecting Your Application for Testability

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mark Trostler
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to write testable JavaScript. This is mostly about applying the SOLID principles.

X.T: GTAC 2013: Web Performance Testing with WebDriver

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Michael Klepikov
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome WebDriver has been extended to support profiling, so it is now possible to automate performance tests with it.

X.T: GTAC 2013: Finding Culprits Automatically in Failing Builds - i.e. Who Broke the Build?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Celal Ziftci
Vivek Ramavajjala
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A tool using heuristics to find which commit broke the build.

X.T: GTAC 2013: Empirical Investigation of Software Product Line Quality

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Katerina Goseva-Popstojanova
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using statistics to try to build a predictive model of which modules will contain the most bugs.

X.T: GTAC 2013: AddressSanitizer, ThreadSanitizer and MemorySanitizer -- Dynamic Testing Tools for C++

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Kostya Serebryany
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Leah Stockley
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using a Visual Test Model, i.e. a mindmap representing the test coverage.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Osherove
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Roy describes the MethodName_StateUnderTest_ExpectedBehavior naming convention for unit tests.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Osherove
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good tutorial on how to write unit tests and an introduction to TDD.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Osherove
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some good advice on writing good unit tests, i.e. unit test which are trustworthy, maintainable and readable.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Osherove
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of system isolation: a tutorial on isolation, an explanation of mock vs stub, a demo of NUnit, Rhino Mocks and Typemock's Isolator.

X.T: Mocking on the Edge - Isolation at the system level

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Roy Osherove
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Typemock Open-AOP API and how to use it for stubbing Sharepoint and Silverlight.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Douglas Hoffman
ARTICLE.COMMENT: This presentation presents some basic, but nevertheless interesting, ideas about strategies to determinate if an automated test succeeded or failed: no oracle, true oracle, consistency, self-referential, and heuristic.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Carl Nagle
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of keyword driven automation and an architecture of a framework for such testing.

X.T: Does my button look big in this? Building testable AJAX Applications

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Adam Connors
Joe Walnes
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An application split into MVC components is easier to test automatically (the View may still be manually tested).

X.T: Video: Ron Adams — Automated Integration Testing with YUI Test, Selenium and Hudson
YUI Theater — Ron Adams: “Automated Integration Testing with YUI Test, Selenium and Hudson”

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ron Adams
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of a TDD environment: unit test framework (YUITest) + test driver (Selenium) + continuous integration (Hudson).

X.T: Video: John Resig — Testing, Performance Analysis, and jQuery 1.4
YUI Theater — John Resig: “Testing, Performance Analysis, and jQuery 1.4″

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: John Resig
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of some JavaScript unit tests and performance tools, some JQuery news (performance improvements, event bubbling...) and some comment on using HTML 5 on Internet Explorer.

X.T: Test your app from right to left

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jason Elbaum
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google releases bidichecker, an open source verifying bidirectional text.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Joydip Kanjilal
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description on how to start with Moles, a framework to mock .NET methods.

X.T: Tools to unit test your JavaScript -- Using QUnit, YUI Test, and JSTestDriver

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Sebastiano Armeli-Battana
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of QUnit, YUI Test, and JSTestDriver.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Seth McLaughlin
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Venus.js and a demo of Venus.js and Mocha.

X.T: Automate acceptance tests with Selenium -- How to use the Selenium test tool for functional testing of a Ruby on Rails and Ajax application

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Brian Marick
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of Selenium to test Ajax applications.

X.T: Selenium: The in-browser acceptance testing tool

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Jason Huggins
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Jason tried to demonstrate how a commit in Subversion could trigger CruiseControl which would run the new build accross several OSes and Browsers and generate Flash videos of the automated tests. But the presentation is very unclear and the demo failed...

X.T: Selenium Grid: Web Testing in Parallel

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Geoffrey Wiseman
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Selenium Grid can dispatch the tests on several PCs.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Bret Pettichord
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A comparison of the two tools.

X.T: Using Fit: An Open-Source Testing Framework

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Rick Mugridge
ARTICLE.COMMENT: This description of Fit is not clear: instead of speaking of the mechanisms of Fit (such as the fixtures between the storytests and the AUT), Mugridge spends his time trying to convince the audience about the interest of storytests, but his discourse is messy.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Gerard Meszaros
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to detect and fix issues in unit tests: code smells (tests difficult to understand, tests containing coding errors, tests difficult / impossible to write), behavior smells (tests failing when they should succeed - erratic test, fragile test -, tests succeeding when they should fail), and project smells

X.T: Test Infected: Programmers Love Writing Tests

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Kent Beck
Eric Gamma
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The two authors describe the return of investment of unit testing and propose their own tool for Java: JUnit.

X.T: Incremental development with Ant and JUnit

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Malcolm Davis
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes how he used Ant for his build process, this one includes automatic unit tests with JUnit.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alex Garrett
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some common testing errors: testing only the expected case, forgetting boundary situations, breaking encapsulation, and too much test complexity.

X.T: Testing JavaScript Using the Jasmine Framework

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Rob Gravelle
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short introduction to writing JavaScript unit tests using Jasmine.

X.T: Using open source tools for performance testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Goranka Bjedov
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some generalities about performance testing of Web applications: description of the different types of performances tests, architecture of a performance test environment, in-house vs vendor vs open source performance tools, keeping all the data for a while...

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Cem Kaner
ARTICLE.COMMENT: After describing what is negligence and malpractice, explaining that tests must be prioritized depending on the risks, Cem gives a list of coverage measures as some food for thought..

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steve Cornett
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An exhaustive list of the different types of coverage measurements, but some descriptions are not so clear...

X.T: In pursuit of code quality: Don't be fooled by the coverage report - Are your test coverage measurements leading you astray?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Andrew Glover
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to code coverage. The coverage booby traps are clearly exposed, but this article is too much verbose.

X.T: Code coverage goal: 80% and no less!

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Alberto Savoia
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How much code coverage should we target?

BLIST.TITLE: The Clean Code Talks: writing testable code

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Luiz-Otavio Zorzella
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of GuiceBerry.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to unit testing and dependency injection.

X.T: The Clean Code Talks - Don't Look For Things!

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to write testable code: dependency injection, separating the business logic and the builders, not asserting non-nullness (in my mind, this advice is very bad and the example he gives is badly exploited: the test assumes that the door is not repainted by the paint() method, if this is changed in the future, the test breaks)...

X.T: The Clean Code Talks - "Global State and Singletons"

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why global state is evil and should be get rid of by using dependency injection.

X.T: "The Clean Code Talks -- Inheritance, Polymorphism, & Testing"

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Nothing interesting here, this presentation is a basic teaching of the purpose of polymorphism.

X.T: Design Tech Talk Series Presents: OO Design for Testability

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same information as the previous videos: do not call new in the class constructor but inject the dependencies, do not perform work in the constructor, do not use global states, and avoid diving deep in the entities relationship to get some data.

X.T: How to Write Clean, Testable Code

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Miško Hevery
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Still the same information as the previous videos.
